Comment: I learned my lesson from last time, instead of unleashing my queen to check the king, I moved up her pawn to open her up from another side, and also her bishop. And I also pressure my opponent's pawn.

I learned my lesson from last time, instead of unleashing my queen to check the king, I moved up her pawn to open her up from another side, and also her bishop. And I also pressure my opponent's pawn.
He does likewise...
...so I capture his king's pawn in the hope that he'd do the same...
...which he does, to open up the d-file...
...allowing me to remove his queen...
...forcing him to take mine, so he can't castle.
Now I accept another pawn...
...but lose mine.
Now I bring up the bishop to pin the knight down...
...so he unleashes his bishop to unpin the knight...
...and I release my knight...
...so I can castle queenside and place him in check.
...so I can castle queenside and place him in check.
Now I remove the knight...
Now I remove the knight...
...at the expense of my bishop...
...and I also remove the exposed pawn...
...and the bishop...
...and the bishop...
...in exchange for my knight.
Now I bring up my knight...
...and as he brings up his...
...I do likewise to my bishop to guarantee a win of at least one of the knight and the bishop.
